definition: capital/assets/savings/nest egg/(fig.) reputation/laurels (to rest upon)/old edition of a book/(tree) trunk

prefix used before the surname of a person or a numeral indicating the order of birth of the children in a family or to indicate affection or familiarity/old (of people)/venerable (person)/experienced/of long standing/always/all the time/of the past/very/outdated/(of meat etc) tough
root/stem/origin/source/this/the current/original/inherent/originally/classifier for books, periodicals, files etc

sentences.english: Then it would seem that the disciples went back to their fishing for a short period.
sentences.chinese: 之后，门徒似乎有一段短时间回去作捕鱼的老本行。

sentences.english: This did not yet tempt them to adventures staking Soviet assets.
sentences.chinese: 这还没有促使他们把苏联的老本拿来孤注一掷。

sentences.english: There is little evidence that America is resting on its laurels, according to RAND.
sentences.chinese: 兰德公司指出，没有证据表明美国正在吃老本。

sentences.english: You should go on studying instead of resting on your laurels.
sentences.chinese: 你应该继续努力学习而不能吃老本。

sentences.english: And so she returned to her old trade of catching flies again.
sentences.chinese: 于是，她又干起老本行，捉苍蝇去了。

sentences.english: He does no business but lives on his capital.
He was back on familiar ground, dealing with the customers.
sentences.chinese: 他又干起了与顾客打交道的老本行。

sentences.english: So now I'm happy to go back to my usual work.
sentences.chinese: 所以，我很高兴现在能又回到我的老本行。

sentences.english: It seems that we can no longer afford to rest on our Laurels .
sentences.chinese: 看来我们再也不能靠吃老本过曰子了。

sentences.english: The guy with just this one song.
Therefore, those who live off their past gains will be looked down upon and won't have a prospect.
sentences.chinese: 所以吃老本的人是会被人瞧不起或没有前途的。

sentences.english: Lovers in like manner live on their capital from failure of income.
sentences.chinese: 恋人在收入有限时也以类似的方式以他们的老本为生。

definition: lit. just sitting and eating, one can deplete even a mountain of wealth (idiom)/fig. to spend one's money without generating any income
deficiency/deficit/luckily/it's lucky that.../(often ironically) fancy that...
to squander one's fortune/to dissipate one's wealth
lit. drink the northwest wind (idiom); cold and hungry

lit. even a scrawny camel is bigger than a horse (idiom)/fig. even after suffering a loss, a rich person is still better off than ordinary people/a cultured person may come down in the world, but he is still superior to the common people
pinyin: shou4 si3 de5 luo4 tuo5 bi3 ma3 da4

definition: income does not cover expenditure/unable to make ends meet
to save on food and clothing (idiom); to live frugally
to lose everything one invested (idiom)/to lose one's shirt
